metadata.initial_prompt: Should social media platforms regulate content to prevent hate speech and misinformation, or should they allow free speech, even at the risk of harmful content?

debate_history.speaker: Phi-left
debate_history.response: Free Appropriate Expression. Do you think that people have a right not only to say something but also to see it online? debate_history.speaker: Phi-right
debate_history.response: "shouldn't social media companies regulate content..." This seems pretty straightforward enough until someone throws in some big talk about protecting women and minorities...

debate_history.speaker: Phi-left
debate_history.response: How might we better understand the concept behind the phrase 'free speech'? Or put another way, "what do people think it means?" Let us attempt to answer both questions. It may be helpful for you to read our responses below after reading them carefully. Also feel free to use whichever method makes sense best (for example listing pros and cons), but beware - very many interpretations exist regarding the term itself.... For now though, please continue reading....

debate_history.speaker: Phi-right
debate_history.response: ‘Should Social Media Platforms Regulate Content To Prevent Hate Speech And Misinformation’ by answering which side agrees with “…any one leader who believes this is their right as president—not matter how good their ideas are." In other words … Which political party would agree more easily that Trump thinks America has lost its moral compass when compared to those who disagree politically? That Democrats have never considered things like white nationalism; anti-gay hatred such as outragingly declaring oneself to be superior over gays — or saying that anyone born black can only enjoy so much success unless they become really super-black – simply based upon skin color rather than any hard work done themselves.
